commentBody: Caitlin calls Kate Chin Park "a relative newbie", which is technically true for the NYT, but Kate is a frequent contributor to the New Yorker puzzle, and is in no way an inexperienced constructor.
This was a perfectly fine puzzle, but it offered very little resistance for a Saturday.

Very nice Friday puzzle. 
No Saturday puzzle this week.

I did enjoy the ODDS AND ENDS in this one,
and these are two CRACK constructors,
but I was ALL DONE much too soon.
A very quick Sat for me.  But my daughter did it 4 minutes faster - the old man is slipping.

My fastest Saturday ever at 6:56. :) Agree that it was quite a bit on the easier side, at least for me, but not a bad puzzle.

(I've been playing some of the older Saturday puzzles from 2006-7 or so from the archives, so I did get a bit of whiplash working on an older Saturday that took me over an hour and then doing this one in under ten minutes. Maybe I'm just not as attuned to the zeitgeist from back then anymore.)
New personal best for a Saturday at just over 9 mins. Is is just me or was that easy for a Saturday?
Too many proper nouns. It‚Äôs a puzzle, not a quiz.

SEA STARS is a technically preferable term for what we used to call, sloppily, 'starfish' - which are just not fish.  Fish are vertebrates subdivided into teleosts (cod and the like - 96% of extant fish species) and elasmobranchs (sharks and rays which have cartilaginous skeletons).  Sea stars - of which many have more than five arms - are invertebrates.

I knew those marine biology courses I did would come in handy one day.
Not too tough main puzzle but my time on the mini was longer than my Monday and Tuesday pb‚Äôs.
Woohoo just got my fastest Saturday by a mile

Very quick solve today, and it's nice to occasionally have a little respite from the grind. Was surprised to find answers dropping as fast as they did, and managed to not  have any typos in the puzzle, unlike this comment.

Thanks, Kate and Rafael!

As Vaer and some of you others say, I‚Äôll say any puzzle with Sojourner Truth in it is okay by me.

‚ÄúYou need not be afraid to give us our rights‚Äù, wow, and we‚Äôre still struggling with that.

I had my usual few dorky jokey moments ( like thinking a GUITAR would be a likely place to lose some dried beans, the way you can lose a pick), 

‚Ä¶but I think I‚Äôll spend some more time wondering exactly what [they] are so afraid of.

When sonneteers watch the lunar cycle, they wax poetic.

(Iamb over the moon about it.)
Nice one.  Hits the difficulty sweet spot‚ÄîI knew little of the trivia offhand, but could puzzle it out with crossfill.  Like a steady IV drip of "aha" moments.

I found the main puzzle wasn't a particular challenge, but struggled much more than usual on the Mini.
I've never seen the Today show, have never read The Hungry Caterpillar, have no clue about US college sports fandom, and have never heard of that magazine. All of which turned the crossing of the proper name CARSON with the 3 proper names CARLE, ESSENCE, and KANSAS, into a lot of time consuming guesswork.
New PR for me at 25 min, so not up to par with many of you. Astounded I had no errors.

This is not a Saturday difficulty puzzle.

1/10

Crossword Revolution D11: AIN‚ÄôT I A WOMAN

Sojourner Truth (who was born into slavery a few miles from where I live) didn‚Äôt endure brutal living living conditions,  have most of her children taken from her and sold to Southern slave-holders, finally escape bondage with her infant daughter at the age of 30, and then go on to become one of the most powerful American orators ever, for nothing.

A Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢ production.
New Saturday best at 9:34, and yesterday was a Friday PB. Today's mini at 2:49 was my biggest challenge of the weekend...

Well, I hope a "minimoon" makes for a maxi-marriage.
That provided me with a pre-bedtime smile.

Hope your weekend is what you need it to be.
Happy solving.
Weds difficulty

I was feeling pretty darn good about getting HALFSTEP crossing TIMESUP without any crosses‚Äîuntil I wasn‚Äôt. And it didn‚Äôt help that SUS SASHA and HIRAGANA were a triple Natick for me. Once I guessed SUS it fell in place.

Alternate clue for 36A:


Plumber's crack?

At some point, I found myself fretting this was going to be a fast sprint to the finish line. But I didn't want it to end so soon, nor did i want to let the speediness of the solve frazzle me into trying to go faster just because it seemed I could. So I deliberately slowed down, breathed slowly, stretched out time, and let it all become a sedate journey through the grid. DOLCE... The serenity was interrupted briefly by laughing out loud at [What might check your id] for EGO. Brilliant. I raised my eyebrow a bit at SUS. I imagined Elvis singing SUS Minds instead of Suspicious Minds. Something would have been missing...ah, yes, a few syllables. But that was just a fleeting thought and not the soundtrack of the puzzle for me. That came from WIDE OPEN: Creed - "Arms Wide Open" https://youtu.be/99j0zLuNhi8?si=UQ13M9wVyUoE305p All in all, a terrific puzzle, one with no glitches and that I was able to really savor, softly and sweetly. DOLCE... Thank you, Kate and Rafa. This was a wonderful collaboration.

Today‚Äôs (1st feb) Saturday was so frustratingly easy‚Ä¶ I always look forward to Saturday as a challenge but now it seems to me it‚Äôs on a Wednesday/Thursday level and has been dumbing down in recent months‚Ä¶. Toughen it up a bit!

A welcome MINI vacation from the bruising news of the day (I have to stop watching, reading, listening to it‚Äîit's literally making me ill, like a very bad ACID TRIP).  

I have a passion for tools and gadgets of all kinds (it's genetic) so LOUPES was an early fill, and there were other ODDS AND ENDS that were also appreciated, mostly because the puzzle was WIDE OPEN for CRACKing, but not mindless or inane.  It was clever and a pleasure to solve, and I was sorry when it was ALL DONE.

Kate Chin Park and Rafael Musa, the inclusion of Sojourner Truth's piercing, timeless, heroic accusation was especially appreciated at a time like this.  Thank you for that, and thank you for the puzzle.

Wow I finished that in record speed (literally smashed my record) But I wonder: why do I do that? Rush through a puzzle when I think I'll beat my best time. That whole timer thing is kind of silly really. I need to stop caring about it, or at least trying to beat my best times. It robs me of the enjoyment of the puzzle. And anyway there are outlier easy puzzles which set the bar so high (or low) I'll never break them. Been solving for 5 years now and going forward I'm going to try to forget about the timer. Emphasis on try! That's my musing for the day. (Many of you got there way before I did!)
So many moos! Minimoon, moos, Sonoma (moos   an), and the moos around 29D. I thought the cows had come home early.

New personal best for me too, and about half my average time for a Saturday. Came here to see if others agreed, or if I was just on some secret solving wavelength. I agree it was unusually unchallenging, but I enjoyed doing it!

One of my faster ones, although I don't bother my head over timings. Another version of 'plumber's crack' is our 'builder's bum' which has a nice ring to it. 
Anyone explain: ASIS, EST and SPA?
A new word for me - LOUPE, not had to closely examine any diamonds, or from afar either in fact.

Well that was lovely. Some of the clues made me smile with delight; WAXING, MINIMOON, CLASSMATE. I naturally panicked at the mention of maths, so the answer was a joy.
12D was a gimme thanks to my Japanese fluent son. I watched in awe as he chatted away in an undecipherable (to me) language when we visited him in Kobe. 
Any puzzle that references Sojourner Truth is alright by me. Especially in these troubled days.

Fun puzzle, although I had some trepidation coming into it, having just failed miserably at the Mini (the longer Saturday edition of which I think of the Maxi-Mini). I usually do those for speed, but I thought today's was a real bear. But maybe it was just me.

Nice Saturday puzzle. Actually surprised to see that so many found it unusually easy. It was a typical tough workout for me and I did have to cheat a bit in a couple of places, but did manage to work it all out. That's just me. A couple of puzzle finds today. First one is one of the more unusual ones I've ever seen. Three theme answers: TABERNACLECHOIR LATTERDAYSAINTS and then the 'reveal': "University suggested by this puzzle's black squares :" UTAHSTATE And... all of the blocks of black squares in that puzzle were in the shape of the state of Utah. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/27/2015&g=47&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ...

Top right was not at all enjoyable. 

A horrible mishmash of quiz answers, a random neologism and an oath that isn‚Äôt anywhere else. 

The rest of the puzzle was fair. Possibly even good. 

Bleh 

Thanks

Never thought I'd say this, but I wish it was a little more challenging. I've grown accustomed to pain in the form of a complex puzzle that takes me at least an hour on a weekend morning. At any rate, I still enjoyed the puzzle and I'm sure tomorrow will sate my desire to perspire

love to see Nella Larson and Sojourner Truth mentions! 

nice puzzle, a little breezy for a saturday but still enjoyable.
ACIDTRIP, CRACK, OPIUM: BIGNONOS! Or so our PARENTS say.

Surprised by so many people saying this was too easy.  Way too much very specific trivia - particularly in top right.  Sasha?  Semitone?  Hiragana? 

Starting with sista instead of sasha and then entering a bunch of random letters in TIRAGA_A is not my idea of a fun Saturday morning.

TIL that starfish are just a bunch of floating heads! I find that both awesome and creepy.

While many of you may have found this puzzle to be a mere MINIMOON, I thought it was quite satisfying, with just the right amount of frunch. I‚Äôve decided to stop caring what day of the week a puzzle should belong to‚Äî if it‚Äôs good, it‚Äôs good. This one was good.
Despite being completely unfamiliar with the esoteric answers to  9a, 28a, 55a, 10d, and 12d, I was happy that I nonetheless successfully completed the puzzle a full 40% faster than my average.

I‚Äôm in the relatively easy camp and I did enjoy the puzzles. But I was offended by the clue for hiragana (Main script of written Japanese). Hiragana  is is used for Japanese words not covered by kanji.   But since most  Japanese words are covered by  Kanji, hiragana is not the main script of written Japanese, Kanji is.
The LDS church asks that folks refrain from the using the 36 across clue when referring to them
I loved EPIPHANY way too long for ‚Äúexperience that will change your mind‚Äù. Great puzzle, thanks!

Ahh, the beauty of and skill behind this grid, this sweet looking grid with its chunky white spaces.

 It‚Äôs a grid design never seen in the Times before and has a most lovely flowy feel.  It‚Äôs so skillfully filled, with gorgeous answers such as AIN‚ÄôT I A WOMAN, HIT PIECES (a debut answer), GO DUTCH, MINIMOON, and ODDS AND ENDS.  Plus, with very low word and block counts, it‚Äôs so cleanly filled in.

Looking over the grid, and channeling Jon Stewart: ‚ÄúHere it is, my moment of wow.‚Äù

My best experience of the solve ‚Äì a rare and wonderful Saturday megasplat:

I had only a smattering of answers in the top half ‚Äì one of them was AND DONE for [Finish line?].  Nothing seemed to be working up there so I changed it to ALL DONE and suddenly ‚Äì and I mean suddenly, BOOM!  That two-letter change triggered a staccato of slapdowns ‚Äì ka-BAM kaBAM, kaBAM ‚Äì and in one mad dash splash, the top half was filled in.  

Oh, man.  That‚Äôs a thrill when it happens, no?

Thank you for that, Kate and Rafael, and for a splendid outing through a beautiful, skillfully made, and fun puzzle!

"Pseudoscientific bodily emanations" reminded me of a museum I once visited in Rangley Maine (we were at the state park and it was cold and rainy, so why not). It's at the home of Wilhelm Reich, inventor of the orgone energy accumulator, which was the inspiration for the orgasmatron in the movie Sleeper. There's an accumulator on site, though unfortunately it wasn't available for use. The museum guides take the subject matter very seriously, but even if you don't buy the theory, Reich's story is relevant to our times. Read about it here: https://downeast.com/history/orgone-but-not-forgotten/ Fun puzzle ! Lots of orgone energy.

This was a ripper that maybe was over too quickly, but I really enjoyed it. It has things I didn't know that I learned by filling in crosses, which is a big part of what I enjoy with crosswords. I even fell for the basic trap in 27A where NYE was messing up CAPRIS, so had to come back to the NW after working the rest of the grid.

Strands thread.  Please enter no spoilers until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #335
‚ÄúHunt and peck‚Äù
üîµüîµüü°üîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ


Sorry I'm late to post.   I was way off base on this one.

Whew! 
I don‚Äôt keep the timer on, 
but that flew by so fast, I checked my stats bar
and I today was a Monday average time!

Howe‚Äôer, 
I loved it! 

Like a DOLCE la leche morsel
I savored the delicacy,
and gobbled it down!

I‚Äôm heading to the archives for
some crunchy, sticky, ego-checking,
marathon-length, butt-kickers.

Thank you Kate and Rafael.

Happy Saturday all!

Really liked WAXING MINIMOONS.

Much, much too easily clued for a Saturday puzzle, e.g.,  "Morphine source" for OPIUM? C'mon, so many ways to make that more challenging.

Solved it (incorrectly, alas) in about ten minutes. Easiest Saturday puzzle I ever managed to screw up. Had RAM instead of RAT, and never noticed the resulting APPLEMART. So a big fail for me, for want of simple checking before filling in my last box.

Please, let's have more challenging Saturday puzzles.

‚ÄúFigure in history and math?‚Äù deserves to be included in Lewis‚Äô clues of the week if it is eligible.

Completed this puzzle in 30% less time than average.
Perhaps the easier Saturday puzzle was meant as compensation for a bonus puzzle that requires the solver to spend time thinking about reality dating programs.

I was stalled pretty early last night and needed to sleep on it.  I wouldn't call it as easy as some people are saying, but I did get there in the end.  
I used Et VOIL√Ä the other day, and didn't really like AND VOILA. The WAXING clue gave me a chuckle.
Technically a square is a specific type of diamond, a diamond being a shape with four equal sides in geometry.
I liked this puzzle, but why was it chosen for a Saturday? It was too easy. I like my Saturday puzzles to take longer because I have more time to linger over them.

I kind of went around and around with this one, having started with ERIK LARSON in my brain...  
Was anyone else entertained by the presence of MOOS and APPLE TART?  The gentle cow all red and white, I love with all my heart.  She gives me milk with all her might, and cream for APPLE TART!  RLS, please forgive me any misquotes in there; it's been a long time since I was in The Child's Garden of Verses.

I got LOUPE at once, but CLASSMATES? and STAG! were difficult...  I wasn't fooled by NEPALIS, but NELLA? Who?
Some CRACK and an ACID TRIP might help us through coming days....
I'm off to a gathering of Southern Fiber Artists.  Adieu, mes Amis!
Sweet and breezy Saturday. Started w Ang which led to Axis which led to Waxing which led to WideOpen ...and the rest followed. Hoping for a fun Sunday....we all need some laughter and joy right now..

HIRAGANA isn't the "main" script for Japanese. Most words are written in kanji, with hiragana used for particles, suffixes, and the like. Both hiragana and kanji are used in tandem in everyday writing, so calling one of them the "main" one is incorrect.

I'm done picking nits now, I swear.

Good morning.  This isn't a comment on today's puzzle.  I'm wondering if anyone else misses the Puns and Anagrams puzzles we used to get on a fairly regular basis, or have they been published and I've missed them?  Thanks.

Love me a Rafa puzzle, and Kate must have made it even better. So fresh and interesting. Sure, it was a little fast, but high quality. Morphine source could have been Cambridge, but it didn't fit üòï https://youtu.be/EthwxA_2lFQ?feature=shared Boston had a great music scene in the 80s and 90s. What happened? Raise your lasagna, all, and thank Garfield it's not Monday.
Great fun! Entertaining and gentle entries - WAXING, MINIMOON, CLASSMATE, and my second personal best this week to boot. IMAFAN.

A quickie, except for the Sasha, Sus, Hiragana cross.  I guess I should have sussed out "sus" from "_us" and with "_as_a" I should have gotten "Sasha."  "_iragana" was no help on what the "main script of written Japanese" is, although no doubt most NYT solvers carry that word around in their back pocket.

This was a nice smooth puzzle, however I found it easy for a Saturday. Lately I have been solving from the archives, and Friday and Saturday puzzles from 20 years ago were well-nigh impossible, with much more arcane vocabulary, difficult and abstruse clueing, and higher reliance on learned cultural references (Greek/Roman mythology, classical literature, etc.) as opposed to pop culture. I feel especially in the last few months that weekend puzzles are trending easier. Does anyone else notice such a trend, or is it just me?

Really easy for a Saturday. Took about 2/3 less time than my average. 

Wednesday?

Congratulations 
* 52 Saturdays In A Row

I fail on 5 to 10 puzzles a year and don‚Äôt get to another 20 or so.  But late last year I realized I was on a long streak of Saturdays (of all days!)  I have been working on it to get to this one.
C'mon-give us some tougher puzzles so we can complain about how bad they are and be thankful for some easy ones once in a while and then start the cycle all over
Are we sure that todays puzzle was easy? Maybe we're all just experts now!

An Irish friend of mine from grad school was visiting the States on vacation, When TSA asked the purpose of his visit, he replied, "I'm here for the CRACK." Well, that raised some eyebrows. (Helen and Jane will get this.)

I'm sure a lot of people may complain this was too easy for a Saturday, but I'm simply going to enjoy my new P.R. for the day.

(Yes, it did solve more like a Wednesday, but after the week we've had, so what?)

Like many, my first reaction to this puzzle was that it was too easy for a Saturday. But taking a moment to reflect, it's a beautiful grid with some great fill and no ugly glue. That's no mean feat, and I raise my hat to the constructors.

Very easy for a Saturday ‚Äî except for 27 across, which seems to be a deliberate attempt to make the puzzle harder with deceptive cluing. Should have given 27A a more standard clue and run this on a Thursday.

This one gave me fits. Just a bunch of stuff I didn‚Äôt know. 

SUS, SASHA, guessed GROWL before SNARL, HIRAGANA, AINT I A WOMAN, MINIMOON and I‚Äôve only ever heard of STARFISH, never SEASTARS. 

Took a full 29 minutes which I call good value for money.

Caitlin, with all due respect, I'm going to quibble with your thought vis a vis, ACID TRIP. Despite what Michael Pollan, might say, an ACID TRIP, may be a journey into a deep abyss. LSD, may unmask a latent psychotic disorder. I would call that a trip to nowhere.
Loved the Shaquille gif. Thanks for referring us to it. Puzzle was good too. I bested my Saturday average by a lot.

AND VOILA? Do people actually utter such an appalling linguistic mess?
Hadn't heard of HIT PIECES in the press, was only able to guess MINIMOONS from the crosses, and am apologetic in saying AINT I A WOMAN is also new to me.
Much cheered to see AURAS clued as [Pseudoscientific bodily emanations].
Held up for a long timein the NW by a couple of bad fills: I thought [Collegiate focus] was going to be degreEs, not STUDIES, and demonstrated my wild ignorance of Little League coaches by boldly typing "retired" instead of PARENTS.
And confess to getting help from the far side of the room by singing out, "What are calf-length pants called?" when the completion of CA___S had been hovering on the tip of my keyboard fingers for a good ten minutes.

Good one, I thought.

Definitely on the easier side of Saturday puzzles but pretty nonetheless. I initially pencilled in HALF-STEP for 31A and was amused to find that the actual answer was just the Latinate translation of the same. That's the English language for you.
Thank you Kate, Rafael and Will for this puzzle. Really appreciated it.

we see AURA(S) a lot here, thanks to those useful vowels. I did not regularly watch Welcome Back Kotter, but my friend Lois did, and often jokingly quoted a line from the show about an AURA (or more accurately "a AURA"). It's a nice little reminder of high school every time it pops up. Today I decided to find the clip, and share it with youse. enjoy. https://youtube.com/watch?v=1feOavfEKmg

I finished this lovely puzzle very quickly for me, way under my Saturday average. Closer to my Wednesday average. But it was lovely and I suppose that leaves me more time to do the non-puzzle things I should do today.... Harrumph, thanks a lot! üòâ

Or I could head to the archives in an effort to continue to prolong my irresponsibility. Yeah, that's the ticket!

Anyhow, I thought it was a fun and zesty one. As usual, I found some items that I didn't know, notably SASHA and HIRAGANA... But I found them very easy to get with the crosses.  

Nary a SNARL in this one but a very pleasant solve.

Wondering why the answer to 9A was somewhere in memory though I haven't heard a single Beyonce song. Maybe I heard or saw it once and it stuck because FIERCE is a good thing to be. (Not to the exclusion of kindness of course.)

I had a triple Massachusetts Town Situation* in the NE with SISTA, INNE and TIRAGANA. I happen to like "sista" better.

*Natick Police, you can stay in the donut shop.

Was today‚Äôs Mini puzzle harder than usual, or am I just off today?
And where is Joel Fagliano these days?
I really wanted 37D to be Sherpas, all though most Nepalis who climb are Sherpas‚Ä¶

A comment on- clue 21 Down ‚Äúplay areas that, despite their name, are actually squares‚Äù

The middle school math teacher in me feels the need to clarify that geometrically all squares are diamonds by definition (definition of diamond - quadrilateral having four equal sides). Although it is true that not all diamonds are squares (as squares also need four right angles). So the infield of a baseball field is both a diamond and a square.

I really enjoyed this one. It was a faster solve than usual for a Saturday, but I‚Äôm not complaining. There was enough crunch for my taste, and the SW was the last section for me, partly because I didn‚Äôt know the author Nella Larsen. I really don‚Äôt follow sports, so didn‚Äôt know of Shaq‚Äôs academic achievements or his work for the police department. Thanks for that background Caitlin, and especially for the gif, which I had never seen. All in all, a very enjoyable puzzle experience on a very rainy Saturday. Thanks Kate and Rafael, and Will too (so glad you‚Äôre back).

Fun puzzle, and like most, I completed it faster than my average Saturday. Over twice as fast, in fact. However I'll never know if it's a personal record because of a glitch in my stats. At some point I completed a bonus puzzle very quickly on a Saturday and now that is my Saturday "record," about four times faster than my average Saturday! I wonder if there's some way to fix that...

Fact: Sojourner Truth actually spoke Dutch and delivered her speech in Dutch and the speech is translated. The famous version was translated by a white woman who chose to translate it to sound like someone from the South (even though Sojourner was from New York) and also added some.... interesting parts. https://thesojournertruthproject.com/compare-the-speeches An alternate translation published in 1851 translated it as "I am a woman‚Äôs rights. I have as much muscle as any man, and can do as much work as any man. I have plowed and reaped and husked and chopped and mowed, and can any man do more than that? I have heard much about the sexes being equal; I can carry as much as any man, and can eat as much too, if I can get it." Not sure what the real title should be but it feels like calling it "Ain't I A Woman" just doesn't work anymore

i find it rather amusing when people comment on how easy or hard a puzzle is, when it's not really about the puzzle but about what you bring to it. i felt a playful kindness emanating from today's puzzle, so i didn't spend much time thinking about whether it should be a saturday or a wednesday; i am just grateful that i got to solve it--so thanks to you, kate and rafael!

my son and i were especially cheered to see the answer for 45A, LOUPES. my father, who died over 20 years ago when my son was just six-months-old, was a master jeweler and watchmaker, and we have a few of his old loupes around our apartment. seeing that word in the puzzle felt like a little hello from him. (he was not much of a puzzler, but he was an excellent scrabble player!)
It took me realizing that RAM was not the first Chinese zodiac sign and APPLEMART was not a dessert to get the piano thing.

well, i had looked forward to spending some time enjoying a nice long solve on the saturday puzzle, but now i am early for my nap

still, happy saturday, everyone!

Sometimes when I'm solving a Friday/Saturday puzzle, and it's going rather well, and I feel good about myself, I remember all I'll have to do is read the comments to find out how easy it was and how much harder they were in the good old days.

So much for improved self-image.
Had Acid Drop for a bit too long. The puzzle was a good trip!
Who puts vanilla in an apple tart? Maybe someone on an acid trip....

ok fun bizarre coincidence:

was solving today's xword 
with tcm on in the bg (mos)
featuring 12 ANGRY MEN
as I came across 46 down
asking for its director!

coincidentally it's star/producer
is also 5 letters

(anyone? bueller? bueller...)

I love those moments!

I never moan about xwords being
too crazy hard or easy
and also don't time myself
but have read in these blogs
and on rex that my times 
aren't even in the same 
hemisphere as most of yours

LOL

also I only do Th F Sa Su xwords
to keep the challenge bar a bit higher
and sometimes do half one day
and half the next if it becomes a slog

I do however concur with many
herein today that yesterday and today
(no not the beatles album)
seemed a bit breezier than usual

of course I have moments when 
I think -- oh yeah baby... I'm killin' it

but the second I do...
I hit a wall 
so I do try to avoid 
those ya dee ta ta ta moments

LOL

ps

I love LUMET
and am FONDA HENRY too

Always get peeved when people tell us how many minutes it took them to solve.  Is it aimed at us who usually have to slog through many of these puzzles?  We are your audience, after all.  I think you should post your stats in a closed forum , among your very skilled peers, where you can all smugly praise yourselves.
Set a new personal best with this one! Solve was fast but enjoyable

Figure in history or math?

Classmate.   Answer could just as well be anything or body with 8 letters 

How about humanoid.   Very unimaginative clue.  Otherwise a good solve.
Disturbing and out of touch to use the word hamas

@Steve L 

My rough count of the puzzles tagged to Kate Chin Park over at Diary of a Crossword Fiend is 30, going back to 2022. (My fellow Fiend contributors and I cover the puzzles from the NYT, LAT, WaPo, WSJ, and New Yorker plus half a dozen independently-published ones.) I'd consider Ms Park a "newbie" relative only to someone like Patrick Berry or Robyn Weintraub.
@Steve L -- Yes, she's one of The New Yorker's puzzle editors.

@The Poet McTeagle 

True that.

@Eric Hougland Agreed‚ÄîI was being a bit flippant, but there are some puzzles from back then that seem nigh-impenetrable and require a lot of working over. The strategies I've found myself using for those ones (finding plurals, tiny footholds here and there) are different, but I think (hope) these delves into the archives are making me a better solver ultimately.
@J.S. and Eric, agreed on all counts. Nice puzzle but far too easy. I also long for the old, truly challenging Saturdays, when I had less time to enjoy a good tussle than I do now in retirement!

@Darcey O‚ÄôD 

The thing is that this week was undoubtedly easy... But that's not really the norm either.  Other weeks have had challenging weekends and even Tuesdays and Sundays.  Is the overall trend downward?  Dunno, but probably.  Not something that can be easily measured.  Everyone's brain is a moving target.  Even an "AI" engine aimed at the corpus would be biased by its predominantly recent training data.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@Eric Hougland I was told there would be no math.

@Selective Walrus 
I thought it was easy (and quick) for a Saturday but I enjoyed it.
@Selective Walrus Yes, I didn‚Äôt beat my personal best, but it took about half of my usual Saturday time.
@Grumpy I'd take the marine biologist's opinion on marine biology over that of an astronomer's any day. But point taken.

A home can be sold AS IS, meaning the seller does not do any repairs prior to putting it on the market.

Eastern Standard Time is the wintertime setting for NY, and that's where the New Years Eve ball drop is.

SPA's may have lockers to store your wallet and other valuables while you're getting a massage or other treatment.

@Jane Wheelaghan 
ASIS : In a sellers' market, no time to argue about the broken door or the outdated kitchen, so you buy "as is".
EST : Eastern Standard Time (US/Canada special)
SPA : They provide a locker to store cell phone, purse, wallet, etc.  as you get pampered -  usually without much clothing on.

LOUPE is French for magnifier. I guess it's kinda like "chauffeur" for driver!

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@Laura Whitaker A rhombus is an equilateral quadrilateral, so yes! A diamond is a rhombus geometrically.

It‚Äôs not uncommon for a word to have slightly different meanings in technical vs. general use. ‚ÄúDiamond‚Äù may not usually be the term usually chosen in geometry, but in that context it is synonymous with rhombus. And a rhombus is a quadrilateral with four sides of equal length (and therefore also a parallelogram). And therefore - in mathematics if not a dictionary - a square is a parallelogram, a rhombus, a quadrilateral - and a diamond.
@Serge Baseball is played on a diamond, which of course is a square.

The word ‚Äúdiamond‚Äù is not a formal mathematical term; some people take it as equivalent to ‚Äúrhombus‚Äù, while others equate it to ‚Äúkite‚Äù, or treat it as either a ‚Äútilted square‚Äù or any rhombus oriented so that the long diagonal is vertical (‚Äústanding on a point‚Äù). https://themathdoctors.org/what-is-a-diamond/
Serge said ‚Äútechnically‚Äù, so I was just pointing at that technically a square is not a diamond.

@Jim I you'd like to get technical, there's no place like Wolfram, and they use a square in their first example of what makes a diamond. https://mathworld.wolfram.com/Diamond.html It's in the non technical realm that people may have various stricter standards.

My use of ‚Äútechnically‚Äù was in response to the clue‚Äôs ‚Äúactually.‚Äù Thanks for the discussion, everyone. Words mean different things in different contexts, and I was just clarifying that in one context a diamond is a square. I guess the ‚Äúdespite‚Äù is what got me.

Please disregard everything I have said up to this point.

After doing more research, there does not seem to be a consensus on the properties that define a diamond shape, so I conclude there is no clear technical definition.

@Serge I would like to award you 500 internet points for your good-natured response here. 

No points for emus.

@Barry Ancona 
This is a great article. The key line for me was when it references the same article that Jay cited, and says:
‚Äú It identifies several ways in which the word ‚Äòdiamond‚Äô is used. The first is synonymous with rhombus. The second is a square rotated so its sides are at 45 degrees to the vertical; this usage is not really a shape, as shapes are generally viewed as independent of orientation. However, this usage is familiar to anyone who knows anything about baseball.‚Äù
That‚Äôs it is a nut shell.

@Jim yeah, I had a fun little trip down this rabbit hole (I did love geometry class in high school) and found this nugget:

Note: Euclid's original definition and some English dictionaries' definition of rhombus excludes squares, but modern mathematicians prefer the inclusive definition. See, e.g., De Villiers, Michael (February 1994). "The role and function of a hierarchical classification of quadrilaterals".

@Helen Wright 

"Craic" just means "fun" in Scottish Gaelic. But "crack" has been used in Scots since the eighteenth century, to mean "convivial conversation". (Burns used it in that sense). 

Nowadays, the joke in which there's some confusion about whether someone means "chat" or "cocaine" is a well-worn classic.

Interestingly, in the last few years, I'm seeing some writers spelling the Scots word "craic" instead of "crack", presumably because of how well the Irish have publicized their spelling. Simon Ingram did it in "The Black Ridge" in 2022, for instance.

@Bob T. 

Totally agree! M*A*S*H* really grew up... and because of that, I think it holds up. I think it started around season four. The first few seasons were such silly fun (Capt Tuttle, Ferret Face, all the antics) but you can definitely feel the change. Especially after Blake died...  and more so after Beej grew his moustache! Har!! 

They addressed more serious topics, while maintaining humor, and Houlihan definitely came into her own and was given the respect she deserved.  So did Nurse Kelley, to a smaller degree. 

Still a good and timely show in many ways!  A show ahead of its time in a lot of ways too. 

I try to judge those old shows through the lens of what was normal and acceptable then to some degree... and not be too harsh but there are definitely some that are just unwatchable now. 

Thankful for the sea change!!  :-)

@Francis 

The comments can feel a little diminishing sometimes. The times some people post are just insane to me. Some people have Saturday highs that are my Monday personal bests. I try to just skim past them because I know that's a different level and time matters to them.  It's hard sometimes though. 

I really try to remember in puzzles and in life that what matters most (to me, anyhow) is progress. I feel good when I see that I'm improving. 

It's long been a struggle for me but I try to remember that my self image is not determined by anyone else's opinion of me or my puzzle times, etc.

sharonmiami, 

Please consider:

Everyone posting here is also in the audience.

I see people posting fast times, but I also see people posting slow times. 

I see people posting how they solved a puzzle faster or more slowly than usual without citing a time.

I see people posting loving or hating a puzzle, with or without giving reasons.

The comments are a commons. I suggest you do what I do: read the posts you enjoy and ignore the rest.

And, as I do, enjoy your solving at whatever speed works for you.

@sharonmiami 

Don't assume poor intent on time sharer's parts. This is a place where we can all share our puzzle victories and struggles. Some people care about time and others care about other measures. There's enough division in this world already, let's not divide up our puzzle community.

Also, the very skilled solvers out here are often so generous in sharing their wisdom and helping newer solvers.... they have definitely helped me be a better solver. 

I'll never be a speed solver but that's not my motivation, personally. Whatever your motivation is, just focus on progress... And have fun! You don't need to compare yourself to others.

@sharonmiami FWIW, I agree with your basic point. I‚Äôm surprised it‚Äôs not common etiquette here to speak of your time only in relative terms (e.g., i set a new PR, this one took me much longer than normal, etc.). I work out a lot and on my favorite fitness forums, folks practice inclusivity by keeping the specifics of their metrics to themselves. Seems like the same ethos should apply.
